replies.msg:
1. Recently, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China has again and again employed theories of "foreign interventions" and "colour revolution" to explain the series of protests, which aim at preserving the freedom in Hong Kong, without any evidential basis. We, Hong Kongers, humbly advise your Party to churn out "evidence" to support those theories. Otherwise, it would appear that personnel of the Ministry are suffering from paranoia and immediate treatments are needed for them.

2. Alternatively, even though "foreign interventions" do exist in Hong Kong, your Party, under the leadership of the respectable Chairman Mao, came to power in 1949 with violent means and with the assist of a foreign power (i.e. the Soviet Union). It is despicable that the Ministry is now being sarcastic to the Party and Chairman Mao by condemning the so-called "violence" and "foreign interventions" in Hong Kong.

3. In response to the allegations that there was no democracy and freedom when Mr. Chris Patten was still in his office, we now humbly submit:
(1) It was your Party who tried to curb the democratization reform in Hong Kong in the 1950s and the 1990s. The strongest piece of evidence would be Mr. Lu Ping condemning Mr. Chris Patten as "a sinner of thousands years" when Mr. Patten introduced the "New Nine Functional Constituencies" Reform, which was in substance introducing a universal suffrage in the Legislative Council.
Another Reference is hereby attached: https://www.vjmedia.com.hk/articles/2014/01/11/60039
(2) Regarding freedom of speech, it is advised that your Party should check: (a) whether there was a large scale protest on 28th of May 1989 in Hong Kong and (b) whether Tai-kung Pao and Wen-hui Pao, mouthpieces of your Party, existed and intermittently published anti-British news and comments.
The above-mentioned allegations are wrong in facts and have shown that the Ministry has failed to employ personnel who possess a basic understanding as to history. We express our deepest regret to such a lack of talents in the Ministry.

replies.msg:
åŠ£è­¯å±Œè¼•åŠ›å•²
1. Recently the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of PRC is constantly accusing ‘foreign powers’ of inciting colour revolution in Hong Kong without providing evidence. We, Hong Kongers, urge the PRC to utilise their state apparatus to fabricate evidence to support its allegations; otherwise, such allegations show that officials at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of PRC are suffering from a serious case of delusion which requires immediate medical attention.
2. Even if and only if foreign powers were interfering in Hong Kong, the CCP several decades ago under the leadership of Chairman Mao has also accepted Soviet aid to violently seize control of Mainland China. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of PRC is essentially criticising and ridiculing Chairman Mao by shamelessly and hypocritically accusing foreign powers of interfering in Hong Kong.
3. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of PRC has claimed that Hong Kong was ‘undemocratic and unfree’ under the governorship of Chris Patten. We, Hong Kongers, would like to make two points as thus:
1. The CCP has prevented Hong Kong Colonial Government’s attempts to democratise Hong Kong in the 50s and the 90s. The current Ministry of Foreign Affairs of PRC is essentially criticising their own policies by accusing Hong Kong undemocratic under British rule. We, Hong Kongers, will not comment on such internal contradiction of the CCP. [Reference (in traditional Chinese): https://www.vjmedia.com.hk/articles/2014/01/11/60039]
2. Regarding the wrongful allegations of Hong Kong under the governorship of Mr Patten being ‘undemocratic’ and ‘having no right of assembly’ of Deputy Director Geng Shuang and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of PRC, we, Hong Kongers, advise the Ministry to research (a) whether there were major protests on 28 May 1989 in Hong Kong, and (b) whether your propaganda newspapers ‘Ta Kung Pao’ and ‘Wen Wei Po’ was allowed to spread anti-colonial government news and opinions during the Colonial Period.
4. We, Hong Kongers, send our deepest regret and sympathy to the CCP and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of PRC for their officials’ lack of basic knowledge.

3. Regarding the allegation supposed by the China MFA that under the rule of Chris Patten, democracy and freedom in Hong Kong are suppressed, the followings are our responses:
(1) It was the CCP which prevented the British Hong Kong government from promoting democracy in Hong Kong during the 50s and 90s. ä¸­åœ‹å¤–äº¤éƒ¨ä»¥ä¸ŠéŒ¯èª¤çš„è©•è«–é¡¯ç¤ºå‡ºä¸­åœ‹å¤–äº¤éƒ¨æœªèƒ½åƒ±ç”¨å°ç¾å¯¦æœ‰åŸºæœ¬èªçŸ¥çš„äººå“¡ï¼Œç¼ºä¹äººæï¼Œé¦™æ¸¯äººå°æ­¤è¡¨ç¤ºæ·±åˆ‡æ…°å•ã€‚

(2) As for the unjust accusation made by Geng Shuang that Hong Kong citizens were not allowed freedom of association under the rule of colonial government, we suggest the China MFA should probe into the following questions: (a) Was there not an enormous demonstration occurred on May 28, 1989? (b) Did the British Hong Kong government ban the mouthpieces of the CCP from promoting anti-government thoughts?
